content: A man has three daughters. Each daughter has one brother. How many children does the man have?

Let's see. A man has three daughters. Each daughter has one brother. So, how many children does the man have?

First, the man has three daughters. That's clear. So, at least, he has three children who are girls.

Now, it says each daughter has one brother. So, every daughter has a brother. If each daughter has one brother, does that mean there are three brothers, one for each daughter?

Wait, that doesn't make sense because if there are three brothers, each daughter would have three brothers, not one. So, that can't be right.

Let me try again. If each daughter has one brother, that probably means they share the same brother. So, there is only one brother shared among the three daughters.

So, in total, the man has three daughters and one son.

Alternatively, if the man had three daughters and two sons, then each daughter would have two brothers. But the question says each daughter has one brother, so that doesn't fit.

On the other hand, if the man had three daughters and one son, then each daughter has indeed one brother, who is the son.

Therefore, the total number of children is four.

If there were three daughters and only one son, each daughter has one brother, which matches.

Alternatively, if there were three daughters and no sons, then each daughter would have no brothers, which doesn't match.

Therefore, the only logical conclusion is that the man has three daughters and one son, totaling four children.

Actually, the term "brother" doesn't specify older or younger, so it could be either.

In terms of family structure, a brother is simply a male sibling.

So, in this case, regardless of age, as long as there is one male child among the three daughters, each daughter has one brother.
